issues.description: The template's example Main calls farm.feed(); but the problem statement UML and tasks (and the solution) specify the method should be named feedAllAnimals(). This mismatch in the method name in the template's sample code can mislead students about which method to implement and may cause them to implement a method with the wrong name or become confused when tests expect feedAllAnimals().
issues.suggested_fix: Make the template's sample Main consistent with the specification by replacing the call to farm.feed() with farm.feedAllAnimals(), or otherwise update the template comments to reference feedAllAnimals(). Ensure the template Farm class (and its TODOs) expect the method name feedAllAnimals() as described in the problem statement and UML.

issues.description: The problem statement and solution use the method name feedAllAnimals() for the Farm's feeding behavior, but the template Main.java example calls farm.feed(). This mismatched identifier for the same conceptual operation (feeding all animals) creates a direct mapping confusion: students reading the template example may expect a feed() method to exist on Farm, while the specification and reference implementation provide feedAllAnimals(). This can lead to compile/runtime confusion or wasted time searching for the example's method in the specification.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the template example use the same method name as the problem statement and solution. Replace the call farm.feed(); in template_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Main.java with farm.feedAllAnimals(); (or alternatively, add a Feed alias method feed() in Farm that delegates to feedAllAnimals(), but the preferred fix is to align the example to feedAllAnimals()).
